page.title: 05BLISS CHARITY AIDED SCHOOL
page.content: In 1674 William Bliss, a wine merchant living in Southwark, died. William had been brought up in Heyford and later moved to London. In his will he left 400 pounds to the village: 100 to buy a schoolhouse and 300 to buy some land, whose rent would pay for the upkeep of the school and the schoolmaster. This money was to be administered by Trustees from the village. All children from Nether & Upper Heyford were allowed to attend free of charge, also any child with the name of Bliss living within a 5 mile radius. The first school opened in 1683. The school, as we know it now, opened in 1880. The outside hasn't changed much, but inside it has changed. There are still 9 Trustees who administer the Charity and the income from investments pays for any new buildings and also for the outside maintenance of the school.
